name: Overview
main:
8.7 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Iraq, almost 80% of them concentrated in Ninewa, Kirkuk and Anbar governorates. Ninewa is the epicentre of the crisis, hosting 4 million (46%) Iraqis who need humanitarian assistance, followed by 1.6 million in Kirkuk, and 1.3 million in Anbar.? 

Large scale displacement persists following the expulsion of Islamic State from Iraqi territory. By 30 September, approximately 1.9 IDPs have been displaced since January 2014, whereas 4 million returnees were identified for the same period. ? Forced returns are also reported as IDP camps continue to close. Returnees in many areas lack basic service and livelihood opportunities, and still face insecurity due to extremist pockets throughout the country.?

INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.8/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.6/10 and 6.9/10 rates.?
latest_developments_past:
05/11: Heavy rains in late October have limited access in Erbil and Sulaymaniyah province. Roads are flooded and blocked and bridges destroyed, cutting off at least 17 villages around Mount Quandil.  Over 2000 people have been forced to leave their homes in Rawdandoz district, Erbil,  due to destroyed houses and risk of landslides. 

05/11: Water crisis in southern Iraq made around 118,000 people sick in the last three months. Heightened risk for waterborne diseases as children return to school and WASH needs are not met. Thousands of dead fish floating in river Euphrates in Babylon increases health risk.
